importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and timeline of the Reefline project, which is in active development and gaining public attention.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with initial phases launching in 2025 and full realization anticipated by 2035. This long-term timeline reflects its commitment to ecological restoration and sustainable development.

keyTakeAways: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef made of underwater concrete sculptures that will host transplanted corals and serve as both an ecological restoration effort and an underwater tourist attraction.
The project combines art and science, with artists like Leandro Ehrlich and arts curator Ximena Caminos leading the design and vision, transforming marine sculptures into living coral habitats.
Colin Foord, a coral researcher and founder of Coral Morphologic, is responsible for cultivating over 2,000 soft coral specimens to be transplanted onto the reef structures.
The Reefline project aims to restore a coral reef ecosystem that was lost to beach sand replenishment in the 1970s, using resilient local coral species that can survive warming oceans and disease.

The first phase includes 22 concrete cars arranged in an underwater traffic jam, designed as 'flowerpots' for coral growth, with the intention that corals will eventually cover and transform the structures.
The project is partially funded by a $5 million city bond approved by Miami Beach voters and is seeking an additional $6 million to launch its first phase.
An onshore marine learning center will educate the public about coral reef conservation, and future phases may feature 57 giant starfish sculptures, potentially becoming a symbol of the city.
Caminos, the artistic director, describes the project as 'public housing for fish,' using art as a tool for ecological revitalization and ecotourism.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef composed of underwater concrete sculptures, including 22 cast cars designed as coral habitats. The project, led by arts curator Ximena Caminos and coral researcher Colin Foord, combines art and science to restore a lost coral reef ecosystem that once existed in the 1970s but was buried by sand. Over 2,000 soft corals, including gorgonians, are cultivated in nurseries and will be transplanted onto the reef, where they will grow and transform the sculptures over time. The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and seeks an additional $6 million. It will take at least a decade to complete and includes a marine learning center to educate the public. The coral-encrusted structures are expected to become accessible to divers and snorkelers in just 15 to 20 feet of water, and future phases may feature 57 giant starfish sculptures as a symbol of the city. The project is both a scientific restoration effort and a cultural initiative, using art to revitalize marine life and provide an underwater ecotourism experience.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
